9.text:
We are preoccupied with ourselves in unhelpful
ways. The clouds, however, know nothing of

16.text: us, they float by utterly unaware of our concerns.

25.text:
These vast, quiet things are always to hand.
There is a constant drama above our heads:

35.text:
Human life is no less active, but it can be
a moment of relief from our particular involvements

41.text:
to look up and be returned to a broader perspective,
from where the agitations of the here and

51.text:
It will all pass, even the current nastiness
and anxiety, like the clouds that seemed so

59.text:
fixed and heavy but an hour ago – and yet
have now moved on, leaving behind only two

64.text:
or three of their numbers, apologetic and
timid before the victorious sun, like the

69.text: cowed remnants of a scattered army.

82.text:
They are an image of patience, and resolution.
Their gnarled, worn barks speak of the hundreds

89.text:
of seasons they have endured. They have bent
and lost branches in winter winds, they have

95.text:
been gnawed at by worms and beetles across
the airless days of summer, they have been

100.text: knocked and hacked at by farmers and children.

105.text:
But they endure – as we might better learn
to do through their examples.

111.text:
All those leaves, resplendent in the summer
sun, will soon be gone.

119.text:
Human life is as terminal, but it is the example
of trees that best and most gracefully introduce

127.text: us to the inevitable facts of the life cycle.

133.text:
Nothing will be forever, say the trees. Enjoy
these precious days, whisper their leaves.

157.text:
They are always communicating: whispering,
exclaiming, arguing (with a rock or twig),

163.text:
confiding (in a quiet vortex), dozing (in
midsummer) or shouting in rage (after a heavy

170.text:
shower).
Like fires, they provide an ideal object of

173.text:
contemplation. Their constant activity enlivens
the imagination. They don’t stare blankly

180.text:
back at us, like pieces of paper on a desk.
They distract our minds just enough that the

186.text:
good ideas, the ones that we hate to ask ourselves
directly, can feel relieved of pressure and

191.text: slip out - and we can make progress with ourselves.

199.text:
We need nature not just for physical health,
but - as importantly - for sanity. No week

205.text:
should be counted complete if it does not
include one or two minutes given over to the

209.text:
clouds, the trees and the streams: emissaries
of perspective, patience and introspection.
